**Theorem.** Let $a,\,b$ be non-zero elements of a Euclidean domain $D$
with the Euclidean valuation $
u$. The [*incomplete quotient*]{} $q$
and the remainder $r$ of the division algorithm
$$a = qb+r \quad \mbox{where} \quad r = 0 \;\; \mbox{or}\;\; 
u(r) < 
u(b)$$
are unique if and only if $$ egin{aligned}

u(a+b) \leqq \max\{
u(a),\,
u(b)\}.\end{aligned}$$

[*Proof.*]{} Assume first (1) for the elements $a,\,b$ of $D$. If we had
$$ egin{aligned}
 egin{cases}
a = qb+r \quad \mbox{with} \quad r = 0 \;\;\;\;\lor\;\; 
u(r) < 
u(b),\
a = q'b+r' \quad \mbox{with} \quad r' = 0 \;\;\lor\;\; 
u(r') < 
u(b)
\end{cases}\end{aligned}$$ and $r' 
eq r$, $q' 
eq q$, then the and
the assumption yield the of inequalities
$$
u(b) \leqq 
u((q'-q)b) = 
u(r'-r) \leqq \max\{
u(r'),\,
u(-r)\} < 
u(b)$$
which is impossible. We must infer that $r'-r = 0$ or $q'-q = 0$. But
these two conditions are . Thus the division algorithm is unique.

Conversely, assume that (1) is not true for non-zero elements $a,\,b$ of
$D$, i.e. $$
u(a+b) > \max\{
u(a),\,
u(b)\}.$$ Then we obtain two
repsesentations $$b = 0(a+b)+b = 1(a+b)-a$$ where $
u(b) < 
u(a+b)$
and $

u(a) < 
u(a+b)$. Thus the incomplete quotient and the
remainder are not unique.
